title: Britain's department stores suffer worst sales since the 2009 recession
text:
Britain's department stores are in crisis after suffering the biggest fall in sales since the depths of the 2009 recession.

Sales in department and other non-specialized stores were 2 per cent lower in the third quarter of the year than in the same period in 2018, according to the Office for National Statistics.

The sector has suffered 12 consecutive months of sales decline.

Slump: Sales in department and other non-specialized stores were 2 per cent lower in the third quarter of the year than in the same period 2018

The figures underline the difficulties facing household names including John Lewis, Debenhams and House of Fraser.

And while total online sales in September were 9.1 per cent higher than a year earlier, department stores saw their internet takings fall 3.6 per cent.

Lisa Hooker, consumer markets leader at PwC, said: 'Retailers continue to brace themselves for a tough Christmas.'

Shops are suffering because of slow consumer demand, particularly in 'non-essential' items, statisticians said.

Department stores have been at the forefront of the longest and deepest autumn sales for at least 15 years, as they try to bring in cash and clear shelves of autumn stock.
